Basic: So, there is a lot of plotting going on in this film, but anyway, the story starts off where a young girl, who's reading a book called, "The Grand Budapest Hotel", which is made by the author (Tom Wilkinson), and then it flips back to the author a little bit, and then it flips back to 1968, of a writer (Jude Law), that he met a person named Zero(F. Murray Abraham), and then it flips back to 1932 of where the young Zero (Newcomer Tony Revolori), who's a lobby boy, and spends his time at The Grand Budapest Hotel. Then, lastly, it spends almost the rest of the film on M. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes), and young Zero of where both of them get involved into murder, theft, and also into some big adventures as well. It's like a box inside a box inside a box inside a box.

What's the deal: I wouldn't say that I am a big fan of Wes Anderson, but it doesn't mean that I disliked his work. There are things that I like about it his work. He knows how to make a great soundtrack in his movies, and he's also a filmmaker, that does so much style, and creativity. In fact, I've only seen two of his movies. The first one, was Fantastic Mr. Fox, which I had a good time watching it from start to finish, and then somebody recommended me to watch Rushmore, which it's a classic coming-of-age film, and I actually enjoyed it. Now for his newest film, The Grand Budapest Hotel, I've to say that this one is more than to be liked. Truly, and being honest to myself, that I really like this film, and there are things that I really like about it. The settings and the shots of it are very exquisite and very colorful enough. I do believe that it's gonna win some Oscars for that. The storytelling devices in the film are super creative, but what I think of what makes it even greater is how both the story, and the characters are so effective, and outrageous. The film does have a great screenplay by Wes Anderson, which it is the best screenplay he has ever written, and it's very humorous, and absolutely brilliant. Plus, the cast is fantastic. Ralph Fiennes, who I see him in serious roles rather than comedic roles, but he actually carried a lot of humor and a sense of awe through this whole movie. Tony Revolori does have a lot of talent, while Saoirse Ronan is getting better and better of her acting. They do make a great relationship to each other. F. Murray Abraham does carry some big emotions in the film, and the rest of the cast, well done job. The pacing does come off fast, but I don't have a problem with it. The ending is pretty emotional, and even though I don't like sad ending, this type of ending does make me feel satisfy. Alexandre Desplat's music is amazing. Milena Canonero's costumes look beautiful. Right now, I've seen it three times, and I still really like the film a lot.  

My full opinion: The Grand Budapest Hotel is probably the most marvelous film by Wes Anderson, and it's also one that takes you in a silly, joyful, and breathtaking ride. 9.7/10

Loaded with extremely high expectations even before being released, The Grand Hotel Budapest is a typical cult Wes Anderson delivery which will either make you love or hate it. Completely polarizing, it is an absurd, frenzy story, with elements of black comedy which actually is quite thoughtful. 

Even though the movie's name suggests that the hotel and what happens there between the two world wars would be the center of the story, director Wes Anderson takes a completely different approach. The Grand Hotel is only a partial background for Zero Moustafa's (Toni Revolori) life and adventures as a lobby boy. Hired by Mr. Gustave (Ralph Fiennes) , the iconic concierge of The Grand Hotel Budapest, Zero gets involved in a frenzy adventure to, falls in love and grows up as a person amidst a battle for a huge family fortune. 

To many the story would seem a bit too scattered and silly, while the character might be seen as too quirky. However, those familiar with Wes Anderson's style and previous deliveries would expect exactly this from the movie!  His typical dark humor, references to the not-so-far-yet-forgotten-past and tributes to the classical film-making are to be observed all over his delivery. Every single shot and frame is nostalgic. Even the actors and their performances are marked by the Wes Anderson's love for the cinematic history. Speaking of acting, the huge list of A-star Hollywood names is a pleasure to be observed simply because everyone is so unique in his or her old-school character. Needless to say, above all is Ralph Fiennes, who character of a player, seducer of old women, yet a perfectionist when it comes to his profession and to hotel management. 

Given the track record of Wes Anderson, The Grand Hotel Budapest is hard to be considered his best delivery. Simply because he has no bad movie and all of them have been an example of classic film-making. That is why, by saying that The Grand Budapest Hotel is another Wes Anderson delivery that matches his standard is simply enough to make this movie a must see !

The stylistic imagery and incredible production design of Wes Anderson has been promoted by this film in both a mesmorizinly beautiful and comedic way. While the plot and screenplay is driven very fast and some aspects of the film's overall story feel a little too broad, I was continually fixated on the visual elements of this film. Brillaint costume design and stunning acting from a large talented cast is able to deter away some of the film's less noteworthy aspects such as its anti-climatic ending. While the film definitely has its emotional and comedic show stoppers, the ending felt very flat, as if the film just ended without an concluding stunner. We always knew the ending, and though the means to getting to there were twisting and exciting, it would have been nice to end on something a bit more groundbreaking and suspensful. The real star of this film though has to be Wes Anderson whose thoughtful, precise yet visually brave direction leads to film into a new style of modern cinema. Something a little different with its various settings, unique effects, deep themes and extravagant design, Grand Budapest may not be as groundbreaking or dramatic as it tries, and could have been, however with a perfect lead performance from Ralph Fiennes, this film is able to create its own path and ultimately can still stick out from the busy arthouse genre with films that are becoming so similar and unexciting these days.

There is no doubt that Wes Anderson is a master story teller. His films are charming to a degree that we can only describe as being in love with his films. But his latest endeavor, The Grand Budapest Hotel, stinks of cuteness. He must have shared notes with Tim Burton regarding one's own stylistic choices, because his pseudo-expressionism borders on self-parody.

It's refreshing to see Ralph Finnes play a character who isn't evil, corrupted, dark, or whatever variation on evil there is. I found his character to be a bit much. In the past, we've dealt with characters who have had foils that I can personally relate to. Royal Tenenbaum was an asshole who was never close to his family, while Scout Master Ward in Moonrise Kingdom feared being a failure. I could not latch on to the suave, over the top M. Gustav. The best acting moments came when Gustave would simply declare "fuck it" or a moment when (SPOILER) someone is pushed off of a cliff (END SPOILER). The only character I found truly fascinating was Agatha and unfortunately, she served only as a romantic partner and reason for Zero to step up to the plate in the film's third act.

Wes Anderson's direction coupled with Robert D. Yeoman's cinematography are without a doubt the most memorable aspects of the film, certainly more so than the performances or the interweaving story (which I found not to be too interesting). The scenes with Jeff Goldblum and Willem Dafoe are gorgeously lit and beautifully shot. Anderson moves the camera around like a dream, creating suspense simply through movement as opposed to using body language or the POV of the characters in that scene.

After falling in love with Wes Anderson with his previous work, I found The Grand Budapest Hotel to be a self indulgent bore fest. Don't get me wrong, this film is not bad and I'm happy that an independent release of this nature was able to find main stream success, but simply put, this movie is "too Wes Anderson." It oozes his style, as I had mentioned before, to the point of self parody and slight groans every time the camera panned to the left or right of a focal point.

In the Republic of Zubrowka, a European alpine state ravaged by war and poverty, a young writer (Jude Law) discovers that the remote mountainside hotel has fallen on hard times. Many of its lustrous facilities are now in a poor state of repair, and its guests are few. The writer encounters the hotel's elderly owner, Zero Moustafa (F. Murray Abraham), one afternoon, and they agree to meet later that evening. Over dinner in the hotel's enormous dining room, Mr. Moustafa tells him the tale of how he took ownership of the hotel and why he is unwilling to close it down. The story begins in 1932 during the hotel's glory days when the young Zero (Tony Revolori) was a lobby boy. Zubrowka is on the verge of war, but this is of little concern to Monsieur Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes), the Grand Budapest's devoted concierge. The owner of the hotel is unknown and only relays important messages through lawyer Deputy Kovacs (Jeff Goldblum). When he is not attending to the needs of the hotel's wealthy clientele or managing its staff, Gustave courts a series of aging women who flock to the hotel to enjoy his "exceptional service". One of the ladies is Madame Céline Villeneuve "Madame D" Desgoffe und Taxis (Tilda Swinton), and Gustave spends the night with her prior to her departure. One month later, he is informed that Madame D has died under mysterious circumstances. Taking Zero along, he races to her wake and the reading of the will, where Kovacs, coincidentally the executor of the will, reveals that she had bequeathed Gustave Boy with Apple, a very valuable painting, in her will. This enrages her family, all of whom hoped to inherit it. Her son, Dmitri Desgoffe und Taxis (Adrien Brody) lashes out at Gustave. With the help of Zero, Gustave takes the painting and returns to the Grand Budapest, securing the painting in the hotel's safe. During the journey, Gustave makes a pact with Zero: in return for the latter's help, he makes Zero his heir. Shortly thereafter, Gustave is arrested and imprisoned for the murder of Madame D after forced testimony by Serge X (Mathieu Amalric), Madame D's butler. Zero aids Gustave in escaping from Zubrowka's prison by sending a series of stoneworking tools concealed inside cakes made by Zero's fiancée Agatha (Saoirse Ronan). Along with a group of convicts, Gustave digs his way out of his cell. Gustave then teams up with Zero to prove his innocence... 

Wes Anderson is a director you either love or hate as I have said before, to be quite blunt. I had a hard time to accept his a bit too ambitious and "smarty pants" hipster sort movies at first, but with "Life Aquatic" and "Moonrise Kingdom" he managed to convince me with his theatrical colourful stories and his attention to details. I reckon "Moonrise Kingdom" is one of his best features, so I had high hopes for "Grand Hotel Budapest" as the positive reviews came pouring in. My first reaction after seeing the "Grand Hotel Budapest" was that is was to be honest a bit boring, stale, too long and it almost felt that he made it with just his left hand. With that I mean the storyline just didn´t engage me at least as his previous movies did. It´s a great cast, but the whole production feels more like an excuse for a fancy dress up party that really leads nowhere and all the characters has this deadpan look on their face throughout the movie. Yes, Fiennes makes an impression as Gustave H with his dry wit and farcical appearance which we are not used to see and it´s always a treat to see so many big names in one movie giving life to all these strange characters. But, to me this became a gigantic fancy soufflé that didn´t contain much more than just sugar in the end.

Wow, what an utterly charming movie.   As I've mentioned before, Wes Anderson films are hit and miss for me, and this one hit in a big way.  I believe this is his best film to date and may even be his masterpiece.  It of course is teeming with his signature style and includes the typical group of kooky characters, but there is a melancholy about the story that resonated with me more than his other work.   This movie is brilliant for many reasons, but what makes it original is that it is so much at the same time:  it's a dark comedy, screwball comedy, crime caper, and a fairy tale (albeit more Hans Christian Anderson than Disney), and somehow it all blends together seamlessly.  The writing is fantastic and absolutely should at least be nominated for an Oscar:  the narrative is tight, the plot is fluid, and the dialogue is sublime.  It stars Anderson's usual army of A-list actors, and of course they are all great, but it's Tilda Swinton who steals the show, who only has two scenes but is somehow the standout performance.  Though I hate to even say that because Ralph Fiennes is perfect in the lead role (as well as newcomer Tony Revolori).   Who knew Fiennes had such great comedic timing?   This movie is beautiful, whimsical, stylish, sentimental, rich, quirky, and hilarious (the chase scene in particular had me in stitches!).  If you haven't already, you gotta see it.  The best movie I've seen so far this year.

Funny and amusingly quirky tale of the history of a famous hotel in a fictional land made to represent Europe in the early 20th century. 
The story centers around a talented hotel concierge and his young protege who both get caught up in the legal complications of the death of a wealthy noblewoman and must go on an elaborate journey to set things straight. These central characters along with nearly all of the others are infectiously fascinating with all of their strange nuances and mannerisms. The dialogue is often very frank and therefore, a bit strange and striking, but this style along with the slightly unorthodox yet compelling cinematography combine for a pleasingly bizarre experience. The style is one of the best qualities of the movie and never really gets old; however, it can at times seem a little artificial and awkward, despite its otherwise overwhelming success. The movie is also quite funny in many places both as a result of its unconventionality as well as its cleverness. 
While the overall style of the movie is by design eccentric and a bit absurd, the plot itself is coherent and very intriguing. In the end, I felt a sense of satisfying closure and delight in the sheer novelty and wit of this well-crafted movie.

Like a delicious fairy tale, the Grand Budapest Hotel is a gloriously over the top fantasy confection. It tells the story of a suave concierge, Gustave H. who has a taste for the older lady clients of the hotel where he works. Gustave takes a new lobby boy, Zero, under his wing to teach him the trade but the unlikely couple soon become embroiled in a case of murder and the theft of a priceless artwork. This film is hugely enjoyable and very funny. It has a cast of pantomime characters and preposterous situations that mean it occupies a world just slightly removed from reality however, it is utterly charming and brilliantly made. There's a stellar case with the likes of Tilda Swinton, Bill Murray, Ralph Fiennes, Jeff Goldblum, Adrien Brody, Jude Law, Willem Dafoe and F. Murray Abraham. Fiennes takes the lead role of Gustave H. with Tony Revolori as the young lobby boy, Zero. Fiennes plays his role with the perfect pitch, balancing deftly somewhere between pillar of the community and a bit of a cad. Revolori is great too managing to be wide-eyed innocent and a quick-thinking foil. The film looks opulent and sumptuous with its 1930s Eastern European setting giving it a suitably grand and exotic appearance. Wes Anderson handles the more slapstick and overtly comic moments well and directs with care and precision to make many scenes genuinely moving. It's a long time since I've seen a film that was this inventive, sharp and clever. I thoroughly enjoyed watching it and recommend it highly.

In the end, it comes off as a Tarantino meets Anderson if told as Life of Pi meets Inception.  Not an amazing film, but artistically is probably the best all year.

Wes Anderson's latest is not among his best; in fact, it could perhaps even be mistaken as a parody of his style. The world is imaginative, the tone deadpan, the cast an endless parade of talent - yet for all the bells and whistles it remains the shell of a Wes Anderson movie, devoid of the usual wit and deep humanity of "Rushmore," "The Royal Tenenbaums," or even "Fantastic Mr. Fox" and "Moonrise Kingdom." In its place is an abundance of oddness for the sake of oddness - we have a miscast Ralph Fiennes as Gustave (a role in which Peter Sellers would have killed); an annoying amount of colloquial "fucks" said by otherwise urbane characters, weirdly off-color and un-funny jokes about Gustave's sexuality, and a far-too-busy score by Alexandre Desplat which never gives you a moment to breathe. Yes, the design and cinematography is beautiful; Anderson's imagination creates a seemingly-endless amount of gorgeously quirky visuals, but without the heart and the wit it becomes a nauseating assault. He wants to make a statement about basic goodness in the face of a hardening world, but after the endless chases through dollhouse sets, the neverending bobsled race, and the paint-by-numbers parade of cameos by Anderson regulars, the sentiment feels tacked on and the film becomes the most un-Wes Anderson thing of all - disingenuous.

"The Grand Budapest Hotel" is a movie that had piqued my interests ever since it was first announced. It was Wes Anderson, but seemed more serious than "MoonRise Kingdom" or my favorite of his "The Royal Tenenbaums." And for me, a Anderson lover, this wasn't necessarily a good thing. His more serious films, "Darjeeling Limited," were my least favorites of his.So this worried me indecently. But the cast looked great, i do love Saoirse Ronan, and the art style looked like Anderson on steroids. A whole building with his quirky decorating style? Sign me up! So i decided to give "Budapest" a try. And i was not disappointed. The visuals drip with atmosphere and color. Soft, muted colors, but colors all the same. The aspect ratio also flips back and forth, a small but notable touch. When it is in our time, it's full widescreen. A few years back, it's the annoying stretched thin version, and in the main story, it's fullscreen. This is just the first, but most perfect example of Anderson's great attention to detail. The whole film is more emotional than his others, but still manages to have the chuckle friendly style that has persisted all of his films. And the cast is wonderful! Ralph Fiennes completely owns his character and Tony Revolori, the young newcomer who plays Zero, couldn't have asked for a better first film. The details, which are what Anderson does best, are abundant here. But the real stars, (weirdly enough) are not his typicals; dialogue, details, art style. The real stars are his characters. Not since "Tenenbaums" has there been such richly created Anderson characters. And that is what makes "The Grand Budapest Hotel" a place worth staying at. At least for a while. 5/5

It's so well done I didn't even notice it at first.

Also, great performances by a perfectly cast ensemble (the mix of accents doesn't even bother me in this case), especially Ralph Fiennes in the lead, whose harried concierge is very different to anything else I've seen him play, but handled with just as much skill.

Great movie all round.

Naturally he seems to be very rich and powerful and it is with much shyness the writer dares to ask him how Moustafa became the hotel owner and how much money he paid for it. As I have mentioned the young writer is eager to ask questions and know such things. To his astonishment he hears that the hotel owner paid nothing. In addition Moustafa seems to lack in a good listener and wish to share the story of his life with somebody. In fact Mr. Moustafa is an old man and obviously needs communication even more than the writer himself. So he starts telling his story. 
Many years ago Zero (can you believe it?) was a lobby boy at the same hotel. He was an immigrant and had no proper documents. But the chief manager called Gustave agreed to give him a trial. In a short time Zero proved to be very smart, helpful and useful and Gustave realized he could trust the boy in everything. Gustave was a sort of the perfect hotel manager to tell you the truth. But he had one peculiar feature - he had a lot of lovers, mainly they were rich, elderly and lonely ladies who stayed at Grand Budapest Hotel. Other actors worth mentioning is Tony Revolori as Young Zero, a lobby boy. I honestly liked him, he did a fine job and showed to be a likable presence. Adrien Brody and Willem Dafoe do good acting out of the material they are given. But I have to say it was only Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori who really stole the show.

Now this is one of the weirdest movies I have ever seen in my life. There are just so many random scenes of characters doing the most strange things. The screenplay while strange was excellent writing. Wes Anderson created this strange world of strange characters. I have to praise him for doing that much but I wonder, how did he manage to write this? I'm not trying to be rude at all but this kind of looks like he was either damn high. Again I'm not trying to dis him! But it did seem as if was that at times. Without a doubt one of the most original movies in years.

But this movie was pretty funny at moments. Ralph Fiennes gives some great moments throughout, he is this wise cracking, rude, self absorbed dick who doesn't care about other other than Zero. But the humor comes from the most over the top moments. I mean over the top at it's weirdest. I will not spoil anything however I will mention a sled chase sequence that just the funniest thing in the entire movie The interactions between characters were interesting to watch. They are pretty messed up or quirky people and that made it even better. 

Now visual this movie is stunning. I can see possible Oscar nominations coming it's way for art direction, production design, and even the score was great. The buildings and environment is unlike anything I have seen all year and it all does look fantastic and again, original. Everything about this movie is original, visually anyway. 

I also noticed a strange diction from Wes Anderson. The way he directed this movie and the way the picture looked. He always had a straight angle, never turned and he would hold the camera in place the entire time. Once in a while he would spin it around but he liked the use continues shots of the hallways or the characters. He even went for using quick cuts a lot. Between the continuous shots.

My biggest complaint is some of the story telling in it. There is narrating throughout but I felt it being more distracting than helping. And throughout the second act it seemed to drag on a bit. But toward the ending it picked up and become much better and more enjoyable to watch.

Overall I enjoyed the movie. It was weird without a doubt, we have a huge cast with only two of them giving really good performances. I think this will be lucky and get Oscar nominations for art direction, score, production design and maybe even screenplay for Anderson.

I give The Grand Budapest Hotel a B+.

Just might be Wes Anderson's best film yet. It's frantic and relentless, moving faster seemingly than one can blink. It is a part of the film's overall charming nature though, as is the quirky humor. The entire thing gives us a creative vibe that is infectious, and what makes this one perhaps stand out from the others is that somehow, in the midst of all of that off the wall creatively it still appear grounded in something earthly and human. 

The story is a telling of an adventurous tale surrounding Zero (a lobby boy) who works for Gustave, the owner of the Grand Budapest Hotel (a famous European hotel). The story involves an art heist, but it is the backdrop of war that really centers the films sense of nostalgia and period piece. 

The visuals move back and forth from vivid and stunning to intentionally ridiculous and over the top. And while the film remains insistent on maintaing its fervent speed, it is never out of control. Anderson has made another classic, and one that can be enjoyed (no doubt) again and again.

Overall  The Grand Budapest Hotel does not disappoint in this regard, I find my mind continually returning to its twisting labyrinthine zaniness.  

My summation of the film is simple.  It's not one of anything: its a character study, a caper, bittersweet, funny and sad.  No one would say this is a film about life, because no one's life is like the life studied, but overall the film leaves a beautiful aftertaste in your mind that makes you wonder if fantasies like this aren't just a little more real than your day to day.

But instead we get a story about a murder, an arrest, and a prison break. In a unique way I might add, since the movie is presented in parts. That is a very risky move because if one part seems longer than the other than that makes the movie look slow. There are five parts in this movie, and unfortunately this movie is not an exception to this rule. I felt some parts, particularly part 3, seemed to drag on for a very long time when it didn't need to be. It was just a prison break that seemed to last for an eternity. 
Regardless of the pacing, Wes Anderson sure does have plenty of style in this movie. With yet another awesome soundtrack for Alexandre Desplat and sweeping visuals, it's no wonder that Wes Anderson succeeded in the box office with this movie. I can't wait to see what visual brilliance he comes up with next.

It is hard to categorize this movie in a genre, because it is so unique in that it is many things at one time. Mostly, this is a wildly unpredictable adventure. There are a few action sequences, yet they show a unique solemn restraint that deliberately reduces them to whimsical events in a plot, rather than raw excitement. Often it is sentimental or reflective with themes of old age, friendship, and young love. Thankfully, the substantive emotion never pulls the mood down. It has wonderfully intriguing characters and an amazing cast to bring to personality and life to them. There are even somewhat mysterious elements to the story to keep you guessing and a few mildly humorous moments. It really defies categorization, but it certainly bears the stamp of a Wes Anderson movie. This is by far my favorite Wes Anderson effort. His pretentious subdued monotone dullness normally rubs me the wrong way. The difference here from his other films is in the delightfully spontaneous and eventful story that has colorful characters with definitive personality. Ralph Fines, in particular, makes an unforgettable with great presence that defines the movie. He is the main character, but his story comes through the perspective of his protégé. The story moves quickly and smoothly and the flashback conversational narration has a pleasant storytelling quality. It is many things, but Anderson brings it all together in one clear and incredibly fun adventure.

Extremely stylish both in terms of visual aesthetic and production values , Wes Anderson's unique piece is one of those few films in modern cinema which keeps your faith in movie art. This is a film filled with old school style , both in front of the camera and behind it. The film swells in its beautiful setting of the 30s to 80s - all beautifully portrayed by the rich production design and the wonderful performance to go with that. Ralph Fiennes takes this beautiful layered script filled with comedy and subtle drama and takes it to a new level with a brilliant performance - certainly the best of the year so far. It is expertly written , stylized by the beautiful and unique elements of cinematography to go with it . The camera was given a character - it's a very unique style of shooting the film with static cameras throughout making the center of the screen as the pivot. The style runs throughout the different settings in the entire length of the film. Another notable piece was the excellent use of changing aspect ratios to state the setting of the story. The story itself , being a short journey of the lead character - wonderfully narrated  by F Murray Abraham. The cast was brilliant , eccentric and the performance came across the screen. Technically the movie is a brilliant piece of art. If i am to draw any straws i would like to mention the slightly unbelievable nature of the miniatures or models used in this picture . But then again that might be for any reason or limitations. However that's a point to be noted as some of the very wide shots do dwell in the realm of uncertainty. The score is wonderfully written , original yet dwells on the period nature of the story. Overall , this was a nice piece of art with a comedic performance with underlying very strong and mature emotional resonance and the credit for that must go to both the script and the actors. Although it might be one of those films ignored by many movie goers - but to those that views it this will be a movie which is more like a portrait . If you've followed my reviews, then you've come to be aware of my problems with Wes Anderson's particular brand of film-making.  You will never read, in any of my reviews of his films, that I think he makes bad films.  If I ever say that, it's because I think a particular film of his is bad and not because he's a terrible filmmaker.  That would be a fallacy.  The problem I have is how often he puts he lets his idiosyncratic touches, whether it be shooting techniques, writing characters, how he frames shots, etc, get in the way of effective storytelling.  Moonrise Kingdom, his last film, and my least favorite of his films, is a perfect example of this.  I think that film had a chance to tell a good story with emotional depth and poignancy, but all that was lost in the midst of all the quirkiness.  It's the same thing that happened to Fantastic Mr. Fox.  He let his quirks get in the way of a good story.  While I certainly gave this film the same rating as Moonrise Kingdom and Fantastic Mr. Fox, I have no problem in admitting that The Grand Budapest Hotel is Wes Anderson's best film in 13 years.  Or, for those of you not aware, when The Royal Tenenbaums was released.  That movie is, undoubtedly, his masterpiece.  I'm STILL only missing Rushmore, I NEED to watch that.  This isn't a great film, but it's very, very, very good  While it's very obvious that this is a Wes Anderson film, fans of his will quickly pick up on that, I think this is one of the few movies that, while quirky, doesn't become overbearing to the point that it makes the rest of the film tedious to watch.  There's actually a good little story here.  Well let me clarify that, the whole story about Gustave being framed for murder and his and Zero's attempts to exonerate him is actually a bit of a mess to follow at times.  I just think that it's needlessly expansive, almost as if designed by Wes Anderson to get some of the people he enjoys collaborating with a paycheck.  There's nothing wrong with that, but if the story was a little more stripped back, it probably would've been better.  But there are characters that don't really need to be here and all they do is help clog up the drain, so to speak.  Of course I say that, but at least even the smallest of characters gets something important to do.  It might not be of the utmost important to the main story, but they get something to do and that's what matters.  Ultimately though, while the story is certainly entertaining, and probably Anderson's broadest, what really holds the film together is Zero's relationship with Gustave and how that develops throughout the film.  It's clear that Gustave's personality, much like is mentioned in the film, is just an illusion.  It's clear that there was something in his past, something tragic, that has made him the way he is.  In many ways, he is incredibly overprotective of Zero and, later, by extension, Agatha.  He deeply cares for Zero and comes to consider him a good friend.  That part of the film I very much enjoyed, the chemistry between Ralph Fiennes and Tony Revolori is excellent.  There's also the fact that the story is set against the backdrop of the impending war, clearly inspired by World War 2.  Because of that, in spite of all the whimsy and fun moments the film provides, there's this air of impending doom.  Like something is bad is going to happen that is, invariably, going to change everything.  Nothing will ever be the same again after the war hit Zubrowka.  I think that underlying core to the film is, leaps and bounds, better than the main story itself.  Thinking about whatever happened in the past that made Gustave into the insecure and vain person he is, much like the women he romances, and that sense of impending doom, that the great war will destroy everything in its path.  How the now much older Zero chooses to keep the hotel running, because it's one of the few places where he was truly happy.  Those are the real highlights of the film to me.  Visually, this film is very obviously a Wes Anderson film, its cinematography is excellent.  The costume design is very bright and colorful, almost decorative in a sense, as if you're watching a movie painting.  I will say that the film is meticulously crafted.  Not that his other films weren't, but it's more obvious here.  And it's also clear that the film was inspired by some slapstick classics.  To Anderson's credit, it doesn't come across as theft as much as paying tribute, while at the same time adding his own idiosyncratic touch to those classics.  The cast is top-notch, Ralph Fiennes absolutely kills it here with his performance, man has great comedic timing.  The film has such a large cast that, unfortunately, nobody stands out as much as Ralph Fiennes, and Tony Revolori himself, but everyone gets a little color.  There's no character here that isn't interesting and, again, that's a credit to Anderson's eye for eccentric characterization.  Like I said, the story is definitely a bit of a mess, but I very much enjoyed this movie.  It's Wes Anderson and his fans will approve.  The unconverted, however, will find nothing to win them over.  While I think this is his best film in 13 years, even I didn't think it was great.  I don't think that, miraculously, this film would make me not feel skeptical when going into Anderson's next project.  I always know he can just revert to his olden ways and just do quirky for the fuck of it with no regards to story.  Still, this is a very good movie.  Can't exactly recommend it however, as it entirely depends on how you view Wes Anderson's style.

Wes Anderson is a highly celebrated director for our time but not one I am too familiar with.
The only previous works of his that I have seen are Moonrise Kingdom and The Royal Tenanbaums. Both of which I enjoyed for their colourful visuals and hilarious writing.
I am pleased to say that Anderson does it again (and perfectly) with Grand Budapest.  The cast that he managed to assemble for this is filled with his usual and a number of others that is too long to list off.
To explain the plot of GBH is a hard thing to do but to sum it up it's about a cast of ridiculous characters all connected to this one hotel and the story that unfolds is part fairy tale, part cartoon, part stage play and part novel.

It has a very distinct and fast paced style that benefits from the well-timed humour and sometimes shocking violence.

The writing is something I can't praise enough.  Written by Wes Anderson himself, he has a full-realized vision for each character and you really feel the heart behind each one (except the ones that are heartless i.e. Willem Dafoe and Adrien Brody).

The bright colours and beautiful snowy landscapes are absolutely wonderful to look at and fully take in.  Snow-covered streets and mountaintops are shown throughout the movie and give you a sense of the fantastical place where this hotel is based.  Also adding to that fact is the amazing set design.  The pink walls, the fancy chandeliers and beautiful artwork placed throughout the lavish Budapest hotel tell you whom the place was meant for.

I've noticed that because of how different and original Anderson's movies tend to be, he gets these actors that have seem to have all but disappeared.  And not only does he manage to get them on board, but also to get some of their best work out of them.

Bill Murray and Edward Norton are prime examples of this.  Completely nailing their roles and comedic timing.  It was also nice to see Harvey Keitel back as a crazy buffed out prisoner who helps Ralph Fiennes character break out.

Adrien Brody and Willem Dafoe as the nefarious and twisted Desgoffe-und-Taxis (most hilarious last name ever) contributed some of the most hilarious and violent scenes of the film.

The Grand Budapest Hotel is one of the most violent, funniest and heartfelt comedies I have ever seen and the characters and setting can never be stripped from memory.

If you were to walk blind folded into a movie, you'd only need 5 seconds to recognize you are watching a Wes Anderson film. His quirky sense of humor and stylized films are so unique that he manages to draw us in to this colorful world effortlessly. The Grand Budapest Hotel is no exception, and once again Anderson introduces us to a quirky setting full of dysfunctional yet amusing characters. In my opinion there was no better setting for an Anderson film than a fictional country in Eastern Europe like the one in The Grand Budapest Hotel where these gigantic and beautiful ancient castles fit his style perfectly. At times his films feel like you are turning the page of an illustrated book from one scene to the next and that is what is so unique about his style. I am a huge fan of his films and wasn't disappointed with his latest effort although I wouldn't consider it amongst his best work (Rushmore, The Royal Tenenbaums, and Moonrise Kingdom are my favorites). I do acknowledge however that his films tend to grow on me upon rewatches so it may manage to make it near the top of my list in the future. Once again watching an Anderson film proved to be a wonderful and unique experience, and I laughed hard during many scenes. Anderson never seems to lose his touch as there are several memorable moments throughout the film.

No one can deny Wes Anderson's creativity and it is just a pleasure to experience what his quirky mind is going to come up with next. The dialogue is brilliant once again and several characters stand out. Ralph Fiennes in the lead role as the hotel concierge is brilliant as is his apprentice, Tony Revolori. The two have great chemistry together as Fiennes' character sort of becomes the parent figure of the young lobby boy, which Anderson always loves to explore in his films. The epic cast was brilliant as well, and it was good to see Anderson's frequent collaborators on screen together once again. They may not have much screen time, but Anderson fans will appreciate every second they are on screen (Bill Murray, Jason Schwartzman, Owen Wilson, and Tilda Swinton). The highlight of the film for me were the spectacular and hilarious chase scenes through the gorgeous Alps background and Willem Dafoe's comedic performance. The way Anderson edited those scenes was extremely funny as well. I really liked the quirky soundtrack  which just added to my overall enjoyment of the film. I only wish the film would've explored the romantic relationship between Tony Revolori and Saoirse Ronan a bit more and that it wouldn't have concluded in such an open ended way. It was still a lot of fun!

The plot is quite simple for a movie as layered as its famous Mendl's cakes (by the way *SPOILER ALERT*). It's basically about a well-known concierge (played by Ralph Fiennes) whom steals a painting (that was his according to a piece of the will, but the piece of the will was burnt albeit there was a second copy that no one knew about until the near-to-end of the film) and he is accompanied by a lobby boy who is also his protégé and the one to own the Grand Budapest Hotel later on. So, craziness, hilarity, wackiness, quirkiness, randomness, everything maniacal, just what you'd expect from Wes Anderson, ensues. The reason it's layered is because of just that, a lot of things happen in this not too long of a runtime for a film and it feels loaded, but balanced at the same time. It's like Anderson knew exactly how much to put in. And the performances were spectacular. Everyone had a role to play and they all did it wonderfully with just as much of an amount of quirkiness added to each and every one of the characters. Even the actual hotel had, what felt like, a soul. Everything felt so alive, the colors of each shot jumped out at you, but it had enough restraint to not make you feel burdened by it. You can see how meticulously crafted this film was.

The performances were spectacular. Everyone had a role to fill and they all did it exceedingly well. But, the breakout from this, the one who stole each and every scene was no other than Ralph. If there is a definition of underrated, it's definitely Ralph Fiennes. At the beginning of the film when I first saw his face I couldn't even remember his real name. He stole the show and his character was extremely likeable. Another thing that worked well was the cameos and the supporting actors. Adrian Brody was a great bad guy and so was Willem. Bill Murray was charming, and so was Jeff Goldblum. I actually felt genuinely bad when Jeff died, but the way it was shot made me laugh, which it was supposed to, because a steel door tore all four fingers off his hand, but they popped off and it reminded me of cartoons I would watch as a little kid and it was meant to be taken lightly. And I guess that's the point the film is trying to make.

It's a serious world out there. And I mean it can get dark and gloomy as shown in the film (through the wars, and the train stops). Everything can get quite sad and messed up. But, the film plays it off as if it was to be taken lightly. I feel that Anderson made it that way to deliberately say, "Life is serious, and things may get taken away from you, loved ones will die, but there is always humanity, there is always someone there that can wipe that all away when it seemingly encroaches in from all around you." This is what the film was about. It wasn't supposed to be taken seriously, but it was supposed to be emotional. And that's why when it was ending and it showed Zero (the lobby boy) at his later years as the owner, explaining to the author what the hotel was like and how it was now. It looked like it was all in ruin, in shambles, even the concierge wasn't there which led to Zero having to get his own key to his own room. The soul of the Grand Budapest Hotel suddenly felt not so grand. It felt dead, and it was no longer alive like it used to be. But when Zero stepped in the elevator and when the author said good-bye, Zero smiled as the doors closed.

And that's when I began feeling tears.

This sick world that has a sort of beauty to it is dying, but that doesn't stop us. We still keep going. We still keep moving. And it's our memories, or past experiences, our very lives that carry us on. And even when the very thing he grew up in, that helped him when he was down, that was in ruins and that was dying, even if the hotel was all that at the present, Zero still didn't care. He was able to look past all the old, all the ruin, all the emptiness, and he felt more alive than ever because he knew what the place used to be like. And he still kept it in his heart what it was. Wes Anderson basically flipped off all the evil that can be found in the world and told it all to go fuck itself because he doesn't take it seriously. This is his personal message, this is his film. This is what he wanted to say through the characters, the story, the acting, the quirkiness, the randomness, the war, the assholes, everything. This is what he thinks and I can't help but admire the man for that. That's how we should all truly live and that's how Zero and Gustave lived. That is the story of the Grand Budapest Hotel.

Throughout the film I thought of it as just a fun experience so I wanted to give it an 8/10, but when the end came and I saw what had happened it bumped it up a point. But...then I started writing this review and I thought back on the film. Sure it was fun and of course it has flaws, every film has flaws, but the moral/point/message of the film stands up tall in my eyes. The film knows it has flaws, but it doesn't take anything seriously and yet it still is moving enough to make me get teary eyed. This is a work of art. It didn't need something pretentious to get its message across; it just needed a competent director that actually loves what he does. This film is what all directors need to strive for nowadays. Because all I see are directors who just don't give a fuck and want money, but this one actually cared. And it made me care.

I love movies. Anyone who knows me knows that fact. Let me 1st say that I've always admired director Wes Anderson's work, but I've always thought that he's been a little overrated. Yeah I enjoyed 'Rushmore', 'The Royal Tanenbaums', and most recently 'Moonrise Kingdom', but I often felt that his movies were best viewed in a museum, or from under a glass case. His films often struck me as a bit pretentious and a bit too smart for their own good.
But I have since changed my mind. And it is because of 'The Grand Budapest Hotel'. The film is so lovingly made, the cinematography is so fantastic, the music so infectious, the acting across the board so fun to watch that I absolutely will put Wes Anderson's name on the short list of best American filmmakers that are working right now.
Here's the plot synopsis:"THE GRAND BUDAPEST HOTEL recounts the adventures of Gustave H, a legendary concierge at a famous European hotel between the wars, and Zero Moustafa, the lobby boy who becomes his most trusted friend. The story involves the theft and recovery of a priceless Renaissance painting and the battle for an enormous family fortune -- all against the back-drop of a suddenly and dramatically changing Continent". (courtesy of Fox Searchlight)
Now that that's out of the way, I can tell you that you probably won't have a more fun time watching a movie this year. It's so vibrant and full of life, it kind of reminds me of an old Charlie Chaplin or Marx Bros film (except in glorious color) where something crazy is happening in EVERY frame. I wanted to pause this movie so many times just to take it all in. 
We are now in July, and so the year is more than half over. This is MY PICK for Best Picture of the year (so far). I doubt there's anything that will be able to top it, but we'll see. It's truly a masterpiece. My HIGHEST of the HIGHEST recommendation! As close to perfect as a movie can get. :) :) :)

The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014) - 8

The setting jumps between four distinct periods; the most interesting to us is the most remote, in 1932. Eccentric Gustave H, prominent concierge at the Grand Budapest Hotel, and his newly employed lobby boy Zero Moustafa live the end of the hotel's golden age as the war approaches the state of Zubrowka. Both will get themselves in serious trouble after the mysterious death of Céline, one of the numerous love aberrations of Gustave. Among her voluminous heritage lies a valuable painting that was willed to Gustave--blasphemy for her family who won't take half-measures to reclaim what should be rightfully theirs. Gustave and Zero will jump on a risky and whimsical adventure until the conflict of interests is settled for the best and the worst. I think it's safe to describe this as the darkest Wes Anderson movie, darkly fun that is. Both for the story and the characters, especially the brutal cold-blooded killer J. G. Jopling, who has become one of my favorites in Wes filmography. Willem Dafoe can really put together a convincing killer act. This playfully eccentric, witty and darkly fun movie is among Wes' most expressive works, in my opinion. The Grand Budapest Hotel abounds with memorable scenes, dark humor and the deviant Gustave H might very well be the most iconic character in this mannerist universe, great acting from Ralph Fiennes. Steve Zissou is still my favorite goon, though. The Grand Budapest Hotel shows greater maturity and assertiveness from Wes, who has been granted with more sophisticated technical wizardry and casting quality in his latter works.

However, I'm left with a faint feeling that Wes may have reached the creative limits of his cinematic artifice. In the beginning, I was intrigued by the possibility that the four distinct settings and narrators could bring something new and substantial to the table, but that doesn't seem to be the case in my perception. Looking back, it almost seems like a simple technical gimmick to persuade the viewer that the movie holds more substance than it actually does. This is still the basic formula used in all Wes' movies, but this time enriched with a strong wistful flavor arising from the fact that the whole adventure is nothing more than the cherished memory of what was live and loved by Zero Moustafa--only this would justify a space-time transition, and only one would be enough. What's the point of four transitions? It seems redundant to me. The whole story is apparently read on the present by the girl in the a cemetery sitting just beside the grave of the book's author, but we barely become aware of it. Other than its darkly comical side, this could enhance even more the notion of distant or dreamlike past, in which case more development in the "sober" present would be desirable. Fortunately this wasn't a distraction per se; just a personal remark to explain my mixed feelings about the four settings and the ending. I found the whole movie very engrossing and entertaining; Wes is an expert of mood manipulation. I am very curious to see what he will do next. The Grand Budapest Hotel is Wes' sharpest mannerism. Highly recommended!

"There are still faint glimmers of civilization left in this barbaric slaughterhouse that was once known as humanity"

The Wes Anderson nerd inside me just couldn't help but adore his latest venture into the obscure, yet fun world of The Grand Budapest Hotel.

In the most lavish, posh hotel in Zubrowska (a cleverly named fake country), the head concierge M. Gustave H. (Ralph Fiennes) is a well-revered individual, even if he is a massive womanizer, but for senior citizens and not young chicks like most playboys are. Anyways, one of his "wooed blondes" Madame Céline Villeneuve Desgoffe und Taxis, or just Madame D (Tilda Swinton) gets murdered and leaves the hilariously silly painting Boy with Apple to Gustave in her will, and at the funeral, D's son Dmitri (Adrien Brody) pins Gustave as the prime suspect. Now Gustave and his recently hired lobby boy Zero (Tony Revolori) must set out to prove is innocence, with comic mayhem ensuing at every turn.

This story within a story within a story, cleverly composed by Anderson and story writer Hugo Guinness, is just a delicious spinning yarn. It could've been very easy to make a story like this uninteresting and boring, but Anderson populates the candy-colored world (marvelously put together by production designer Adam Stackhousen) with some pretty interesting and memorable characters, including a lovable rogue in M. Gustave H., played exquisitely by Ralph Fiennes. Included is a wonderful who's who cast ensemble that ranked amongst the very best I've seen in a Wes Anderson film, all of whom pull of great jobs even if they are only onscreen for but a few minutes. Noticeable standouts include Adrien Brody as the potty-mouthed, revenge-filled son of Madame D, and Willem Dafoe as J.G. Jopling, my favourite character, as Dmitri's emotionless assassin.

As huge of a Wes Anderson nerd I am, it's debatable as to whether or not this is his greatest film to date, but I think it is the most "Anderson-y" of the films he's done. This is in every way his film and his style. I love how no other filmmaker has the balls to make films like this, and for his individuality in a world where there are remakes and sequels that plague theatres is always welcomed. I go into further detail in my Moonrise Kingdom review, and while he does turn some off just by how "weird" he is, I have a strong feeling that homey knows exactly what he's doing.

Like the opening quote details, which is in my mind more true today than it ever has, and the story, about the humor and heartbreak of relationships is brilliantly weaved in Anderson's glorious script. The humorous moments gave me frequent chuckles, from the subtle to the macabre, but it also provides an interestingly thoughtful take on how friendships work. Gustave's deliciously prickish attitude coupled with Zero's quiet innocence quite literally makes this film, if you ask me. For as so much visual splendor is in hotel, and how much charm is in the concierge, I felt that the flick has a wonderful beating heart underneath all that deliciousness.

While not as funny as Fantastic Mr. Fox, or as magical as Moonrise Kingdom (I actually still say that Moonrise is the better feature), The Grand Budapest Hotel shines both as a humorous, candy-coated period piece but also as a thoughtful work on relationships. M. Gustave H. and his little lobby boy Zero are just as entertaining now, as they undoubtedly will be during repeated viewings, and if you are as big of a Wes Anderson fan as I am, then be sure to check into this hotel whenever you get the opportunity.

***1/2 out of ****
FINAL VERDICT: 88%

Anderson's stylistic approach makes light of and fantasizes often dreary, sophisticated themes creating adult fairytales. The Grand Budapest Hotel is no exception and compartmentalizes a thrilling wondrous adventure into a world and time that's seemingly impossible of such things.

What sticks out in this film is not only how his focus on quirky storytelling juxtaposes many of the darker occurrences of Gustave's tale, but also how it was acknowledged from Zero's recollection as a fantasy. That the beauty, charm, and humor that we were all enjoying was simply in a man... too "civil" for this world.

It's an interesting character study of illusion and one's ability to create a veil of existence that's even contagious to those around him. The idealized romance between Zero and Agatha, successful escape from prison, reclamation of his innocence and rise to fortune was all just so slightly mired with murder, sacrifice, and untimely deaths all around. It's like a careful dance between a dream and actuality.

I recall 2012's "Life of Pi", where I feel that movie failed this succeeded by utilizing a comedic undertone to capture the viewer's imagination before deconstructing it's beauty with harsh realities. There's an endless supply of offbeat laughs and thrills before we're brought to a cathartic conclusion.

Wes Anderson's latest movie, The Grand Budapest Hotel, may be the writer/director's best work to date. His normal brilliance is apparent through the duration of the dramatic comedy, making for 99 minutes of cinematic genius.

Riveting performances by Ralph Fiennes as the esteemed and unquestionably refined, concierge Gustave H, paired with his eager to learn sidekick, lobby boy Zero Moustafa (Tony Revolori), are the steam that keeps this comedy/drama engine running.

The tale of how the famed Grand Budapest hotel fell into the hands of a refugee lobby boy (Zero Mustafa) plays out marvelously. The adventure the two embark on is as grandiose as it is captivating. Wes Anderson's mind creates a universe that is fun and goofy, with dashes of explicit, which provides sheer entertainment value throughout this movie.

The story is quickly teased by The Author as an old man (Tom Wilkinson - present day). Wilkinson grips your attention from the start, before jumping to an earlier time, where The Author as a young man (Jude Law), encounters the older Zero Moustafa, further teasing the story's true inception. By the time the story finds its footing, Wes Anderson has you completely enthralled, following Fiennes and his protege Zero on this creative caper.

It doesn't take long for the ride to begin after an organic meeting between the Author and enigmatic Grand Budapest owner, Zero Moustafa takes place. Shortly after, a dinner is agreed upon so the mysterious owner, who resides in the building in a room the size of a storage closet, can share his remarkable tale to the curious Author. The story then jumps to an even earlier time where the legendary fable of concierge and lobby boy truly begins.

Gustave's charm matches the quality of the affluent company he keeps down to the Lair de Panache he is seldom without. The systematic and overly charismatic concierge, is the toast of the Grand Budapest as well as the mastermind behind its inner workings. His calculated approach is shared with lobby boy Zero, who begins as pupil to the meticulous concierge, before forming a brother-like bond with his eccentric teacher.
Gustave H's close nit connectedness to every minute detail of the Grand Budapest, enables him to wine and bed some of its wealthier inhabitants, while building invaluable relationships. Gustave's brashness is wildly comedic, making it acceptable and endearing to the characters in the story and audience alike.

The concierge's curious relationship with one hotel guest in particular, Madame Céline Villeneuve Desgoffe-und-Taxis (Tilda Swinton), is the catalyst behind Gustave's imprisonment. His relationship with the countess is inextricably linked to his fate throughout the film. Even in prison, Gustave embraces his fate with charm and grace, his charisma never fleeting.
After Gustave is framed for murder the story takes an unexpected turn, the twists and turns along the way to proving his innocence set up entertaining challenge after challenge, offering intrigue throughout the film as they work to prove Gustave's innocence.

As with most Wes Anderson pictures, there are masterfully crafted characters, whose quirks accompany the quick-witted dialogue that progresses the film from opening through credits.

Other Wes Anderson staples, such as cameos and select roles from a familiar cast of characters (a laundry list of talent), are present, some of which you will wish had a larger role in this very intelligent story. All-in-all The Grand Budapest Hotel is a thoroughly impressive effort that deserved the veneration it has received thus far.

----------------------------------------------------
We start the film with an Author, in his later years, doing a video recording.  He then promises to tell the audience how he came to know a particular story.

We switch back to 1968, when the Young Writer was staying at the Grand Budapest Hotel, which was in its fading, twilight years.  The Young Writer meets Mr. Moustafa, who tells him the story of how he came to own the Grand Budapest Hotel.

We switch back to 1932; the new Lobby Boy (Zero) begins his tutelage with M. Gustave.  Gustave likes older, rich, blonde women, and he romances them.  In particular, Madame D. is quite fond of him.  She is on a trip, and has a presentiment of death.  Sure enough, she dies in the town where she traveled to.  Gustave and Zero hurry to see her, and are there in time to hear the reading of the will.  The surprise is that she willed the priceless painting 'Boy with Apple' to Gustave.  The family is furious, and Gustave is accused of her murder, but not before Zero and he secreted the painting.

Mr. Moustafa pauses to describe his relationship to Agatha, who works in the bakery of the hotel.  Agatha helps in the escape of Mr. Gustave.  Then Moustafa returns to the investigation of Madame D's death, and the process of bringing the probate to a legally sound close.

Mr. Gustave, with the aid of Zero and four fellow prisoners, escapes prison.  Gustave reaches for help from his fellow concierge friends.

In the counter-theme, Dmitri and his cohort Jopling, pursue Gustave for the sake of the painting, mostly.

Will anyone find Serge, supposedly the real culprit in the death of Madame D. ?   Do we get to know how Zero gets enough money to buy the Grand Budapest?  Will Zero and Agatha ever get together legally?  What will become of Dmitri and Jopling?  Will Henckles re-capture Gustave or Zero?

-----Scores-----
Cinematography: 10/10 Fine job.

Sound: 10/10 Well done.  Sometimes wildly inappropriate but usually good for a laugh or two.

Acting: 10/10  What a cast!  Great jobs by most involved.  No bad performances.

Screenplay: 6/10 The main plot is so stupid it is beyond belief, but one assumes that was on purpose.  I got several belly laughs, dozens of smiles, and double handful of chuckles.

A delightful film to watch, but somehow I still feel some degree of emotional detachment, which makes the (quite suddenly) sentimental remarks by the old Zero at the end not as effective as I expected. Well, maybe that is the intention of Wes Anderson after all - making a film for the audience to enjoy (and indeed it is enjoyable, and hugely popular - as a Wes Anderson film) and not to frown (I prefer The Royal Tenenbaums in this aspect - a film that can balance both). It's good to see Wes Anderson still keeps up his spirit after all those years.

With The Grand Budapest Hotel, Anderson gives us a rollicking comedy about a hotel concierge (Fiennes) who is framed for the murder of a wealthy guest (Swinton) who has left him a fortune.  With the help of his trusty lobby boy (Revolori) he must escape prison and clear his name, just as Europe falls into war. You pretty much should know what you will be getting in terms of tone with a Wes Anderson movie, and this is no exception. The star studded cast are all very entertaining to watch (in small and large roles alike), and the production design is a triumph of style and colours, as is Alexander Desplat's breathlessly peppy score - but, for a movie that behaves like a comedy, instances of laughter are actually not so many, and the whole affair borders on caricature so often, the potential drama inherent to the story is diffused, and  the anachronistic expletive laden dialogue and occasional attempts  at  visceral violence are no compensation for it.

OK, bottom line--would I recommend people go see this? Sure, with some reservations. It was silly and fun with great pacing, lots of enjoyable cameos and fascinating production values, location and interior shots (real or CGI). And the relationship between the lobby boy and his girlfriend (and to a lesser extent between the lobby boy and the Ralph Fiennes character) demonstrated some depth of feeling, but that said, and since two of those three characters were dead at the telling, I found the movie essentially "soul-less"--very clever and sophisticated but fairly empty and dark at its core.

Wes Anderson's film is decently paced, written moderately well, and contains a bevy of talented actors who all conspire to do their part, but falls just short of consistently capturing attention and drawing laughs with its comedic intention.Wes Anderson's film is decently paced, written moderately well, and contains a bevy of talented actors who all conspire to do their part, but falls just short of consistently capturing attention and drawing laughs with its comedic intention. It's just too eccentric for its own good. Far too many times were the laughs forced, as if the few members of the audience were laughing out of a desire to show themselves they "got the joke". By no means was it a bad film, however. The filming style was fairly straightforward but well done. Shots were pleasingly spaced and different ratios chosen for different time periods, effectively separating the periods without any intrusion or confusion for the audience. The set design and chosen locations fit the tone and general "feel" of the plot. The actors played each character off of one another to create some creatively comedic moments as well as others filled with tension. With a few exceptions - Edward Norton's peculiar character - the dialogue was performed well; Ralph Fiennes in particular did a wonderful job. Despite these positives, the  unneccsariy eccentricity of the film combined with its wholly uninteresting plot made the film rather tedious to sit through. Although it was, perhaps, not technically a comedy, The Grand Budapest Hotel certainly tried to appear like one but did little to capitalize on the actors it was given. The comedy fell short of being funny in nearly all cases, save for a few here and there. The moments were obvious and some juvenile in their humor. The film did have a novel or bookish feel to it - its plot seemed better suited to a written medium, but it was effectively conveyed on film. Though it did succeed in some areas, The Grand Budapest Hotel failed to consistently produce an interesting narrative and tried to hard to be a comedy combined with an odd plot. It was an above average film, but only just so, and with a veteran director in Wes Anderson with a talented cast in did not rise to the occasion and meet expectations.

“You see, there are still faint glimmers of civilization left in this barbaric slaughter house that was once known as humanity”.  If there was ever a quote to sum up the films of Wes Anderson, this would be high on the list. Highly inventive,“You see, there are still faint glimmers of civilization left in this barbaric slaughter house that was once known as humanity”.  If there was ever a quote to sum up the films of Wes Anderson, this would be high on the list. Highly inventive, absurd, and at times, narratively incoherent, Anderson’s eighth feature film is a grand, accommodating feature whose self is probably not as grand as the cast it has rounded out. From Ralph Fiennes, Harvey Kietel, Bob Balaban, Saoirse Ronan, Lea Seydoux, to regulars Tilda Swinton, Adrien Brody, Jason Schwartzman and of course Bill Muarry, The Grand Budapest Hotel is a formidably full house of A-list actors who happily lend their skills to the highly inventive and immensely visual Anderson. Aside from the wholly impressive cast, is the quirky and unmistakably unique vision of Anderson himself. If you haven’t been fortunate enough to experience a Wes Anderson film yet, you are surely missing out on one of the most elaborate, detailed, and symmetrical styles of film-making ever known.  Anderson’s style, renown and admired by many, may very well be the American indie art-house King and The Grand Budapest Hotel may very well be his grandest and most admirable spectacle yet–although it may not be his most engaging or beloved. The Grand Budapest Hotel is an empirical picture, in every sense of the word. Throughout his career as a writer/director, Anderson has defined and refined his vision to the point that every heist; every adventure; or every group of individuals, can easily be distinguishable, as if their existence could only be understood within an Anderson film. The essence of the characters within The Grand Budapest, as well as his overall vision, is creatively maintained thanks to the purity of the scenarios and wackiness of the characters Anderson houses, in whatever setting it may be. For decades now, Anderson has bequeathed to film-lovers everywhere and audiences’ alike, a signature style unlike any other. There are countless films where the characters have come secondary only to the immense and elaborate setting they are placed in. For example, in many films urban settings; New York City has played a pivotal role (see: Shame and Annie Hall), The Wild West (see: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada, Unforgiven), and exotic locales within Europe set the landscape for timeless stories of intrigue, lust, love and tragedy (see: Vicky Cristina Barcelona and The Bicycle Thief.). In Anderson’s world, although many of his settings are within the very real world we live in today, sublets of his world are envisioned within our world, and in essence, these locales become the greatest character of them all, housing very small, intricate tales of the people whose stories are shared in its presence. The setting this time, is none other than the Grand Budapest. A hotel, that houses the highly empathetic new lobby boy Zero (Tony Revolori) and his journey to becoming the irreplaceable sidekick to the one and only infamous concierge M. Gustave H (Ralph Fiennes). Among the many other patrons of the hotel and each of their individual secrets, tall tales, and life memories, Anderson centres the film around a priceless painting, now put in the hands of Gustave thanks to death of M. Gustave’s latest deceased romance, the mysteriously elder Madame D (an unrecognizable Tilda Swinton). What transpires, is an array of fantastical plot schemes and recanted storytelling that may only make sense when mentioning the name of Wes Anderson. Like any other Anderson film, the stories are only secondary to their execution. Anderson’s films are the closet things to mathematical proofs, where the process of plot-making comes first before the final, usually predictable and happy outcome. Anderson may have come off one of his most cherished screenplays with his last film Moonrise Kingdom, and The Grand Budapest Hotel may in no way trump it, but thankfully, it never tries. Instead, after exploring the unfathomable bond between young lovers, Anderson penetrates deep and long the affections of friendship and the importance of patronage within the industry of service and hospitality. Surprisingly this is a theme that he has yet to encounter, especially after his beloved muse and frequent collaborator Kumar Pallana passed and served as nothing less than a staple to the Anderson cannon. Think of The Grand Budapest Hotel as a large and completely dysfunctional family taking care of you, much like Anderson’s earlier work The Royal Tenenbaums, only this time, imagine them slotted at the other end of a hotel reception desk.

If at any point you ever doubted director/writer Wes Anderson’s visual poetic skill, The Grand Budapest Hotel should slap some sense right back into you. Anderson’s newest film is as absurdist as it is serious, as artistic as it is comical,If at any point you ever doubted director/writer Wes Anderson’s visual poetic skill, The Grand Budapest Hotel should slap some sense right back into you. Anderson’s newest film is as absurdist as it is serious, as artistic as it is comical, and as real as it is unreal. Instead of using the illusion of film to emulate realistic circumstances, Anderson uses reality to write poetry and turn it into something of a fantasy, a stylish nursery rhyme for adults. His efforts are beyond respectable – even beyond laudable – and although it’s early to say, I doubt any comedy this year will usurp Anderson’s throne.Some may argue that Anderson’s cinematographic style – ridiculously symmetric frames, angular pans, and a severely limited color palate, for starters – has become more of a shtick by now, a self-mockery of sorts. However, The Grand Budapest retorts that Anderson is not banking on these techniques to carry his film. Rather, they have become the backdrop to his stage, his hour-and-thirty-minute signature all over the film. Looking beyond that, the viewer discovers how much Anderson has truly matured in his narrative, writing, and directing skills. Behind the Anderson façade is a truly significant and beautifully crafted film, rife with guiltless humor, dramatic progression, and plenty of gasp-inducing moments (some from sheer admiration, and some from severed fingers).With The Grand Budapest, Anderson is not looking to write a film; he wants to tell a story. Principally evident in the multilayered frame narrative, he wants the audience to feel like they’re being told a story passed down among generations, re-imagined in fanciful colors and whimsical set pieces. The structure and timing of the storyline is absolutely flawless – the film never skips a beat. Neither over-edited nor under-edited, the story expresses capricious originality while maintaining gravity and poise. Like many of Anderson’s films, the writing is laced with subtle sociopolitical themes – however, with the turmoil of war and aristocratic corruption running concurrently with the plot, these themes tend to remain in the foreground of the narrative. Which isn’t a problem, because instead of detracting from the film’s hilarity, they instead add to its reputation.The Grand Budapest is gifted with a strong cast, lead by an impeccable performance from Ralph Fiennes. You would not have instantly pictured Fiennes as the ideal actor to play M. Gustave, the charming, fruity, and unashamedly frank concierge of the legendary Grand Budapest Hotel. However, once you see him in his prime, you can’t imagine anyone else better suited for the role. Just about everyone in the Anderson ensemble makes an appearance, Tony Revolori makes a stellar big-screen debut as the wide-eyed lobby boy/companion to M. Gustave, and Willem Dafoe plays an uproariously threatening and stylishly scary assassin, just to name some standouts. Anderson proves, for the umpteenth time, he is just as great a director as he is a writer, orchestrating many of the action/chase scenes with skillful awareness and a definite vision. Barney Pilling and Anderson work together to produce arguably the most appropriate editing I’ve ever seen in an Anderson film. The quick, sharp, and angular cuts sustain the storytelling vibe while preventing the boisterous colors and set pieces from becoming a strain on the eyes. In summary, The Grand Budapest Hotel is a powerfully designed, painstakingly acute, drop-dead fashionable, and laudably jocular comedy-drama that represents Wes Anderson’s skill set in his prime. We can only hope that he continues to create films that shine with such ingenuity and technical finesse. FINAL SCORE: 95 (almost perfect ----------o---------- perfect)

Wonderful and delightful and funny and inspired. Made with Wes Anderson's normal fastidious attention to detail, with careful compositions and eccentrically droll characters (with the exception of the inspired M. Gustave played by RalphWonderful and delightful and funny and inspired. Made with Wes Anderson's normal fastidious attention to detail, with careful compositions and eccentrically droll characters (with the exception of the inspired M. Gustave played by Ralph Fiennes, a mannered sophisticate with just the right amount of rapscallion that instead of quirky tics, he's a man of desires and decency, an almost real human being). The Grand Budapest Hotel operates on a more plot-centric level than any of Anderson's previous films, and yet retains all his charms and idiosyncrasies, yet by not flaunting his mannerisms as character development or deepness of thought, he actually winds up saying more about everyone and everything by letting them speak for themselves. The melancholy passing of the old world is captured in the sheer joy and exuberance of the scenes taking place there, so that when we are lurched back to the present and the film slows down and hits the notes of normal Anderson faire, it carries with it a sense of loss and sorrow. The juxtaposition of the looming war, with its brutality and chaos, also inspires the scenes in the past as they are full of atypical for Anderson indecency. From the dropping of F-bombs to the explicit, yet not grotesque, gore. These seeming anachronisms, that work on two different levels, are both funny and deep and since they don't just have to be deep they actually work perfectly. The movie plays out in three different aspect ratios, a fun little treat for cinema fans who notice. Although it should be said that the majority of the film takes place in the past and as such uses a near full screen ratio (a relic of old European films), which is a little disappointing considering how gorgeous the filmmaking is. It could have been bigger and better.

In the present the audience meets Zero Moustfa (F. I have finally seen a Wes Anderson film that I like. The mind bogglingly clever screenplay tips its hat to past eras of film making, but is very much a piece of writing that has Anderson's signature all over it. This, for once, is a good thing. The design of the film, as in a lot of Anderson's work, is just beautiful and many effects are visually striking. A positive roster of character actors contribute to the fun (Saoirse Ronan's lack lustre turn aside) with Tllda Swinton and  Willem Dafoe standing out. Everything is elevated, however, by the absolutely brilliant performance of Ralph Fiennes which is second only to his Amon Goeth in Schindler's List. I may still have reservations about Anderson and to a lesser extent this film, but if Fiennes isn't nominated for an Oscar next  year for this deliciously sublime portrayal then that will be more of a farce than the film itself.

Zero, a junior lobby boy, becomes Gustave's friend and protege. Gustave prides himself on providing first-class service to the hotel's guests, including satisfying the sexual needs of the many elderly women who stay there. When one of Gustave's lovers dies mysteriously, Gustave finds himself the recipient of a priceless painting and the chief suspect in her murder.
